journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy

title-group.article-title: Mechanisms of steam turbine blade particle erosion and crucial parameters for minimizing blade erosion

article-meta.aff: 1Institute of Turbomachinery, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an, People's Republic of China
2Shenhua Guohua (Beijing) Electric Power Research Institute Co. Ltd, Beijing, People's Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Jing-ru Mao, Institute of Turbomachinery, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an 710049, People's Republic of China. Email: maojingru@gmail.com

abstract.p: Reducing the solid particle erosion of blades is crucial to increasing the service life, reliability and cost of steam turbines. In this article, we performed many three-dimensional numerical simulations on the trajectory and erosion of solid particles in turbine cascades, and the relationship between the structural parameters of cascades and erosion characteristics was systematically studied. The results indicated that the erosion damage to the blade depends mainly on the first impingement of every solid particle on the wall after entering into the cascades, and the erosion rate of the first impingement is much larger than that caused by additional impingements on the wall after rebounding of the particle. Furthermore, it was also found that the structure parameter G = (by−t)/bx of the cascade and the attack angle (α) of the steam admission are the most important parameters of blade erosion resistance. Increasing G or α would shift the position of the particle’s first impingement toward the leading edge of the blade. The most effective way of increasing the erosion resistance of the blade is to select an appropriate G while considering the particle size and attack angle (α) required to prevent ferric oxide particles from causing serious erosion on the trailing edge. All of these achievements are important in the blade selection and anti-solid particle erosion optimization processes when designing a new turbine or upgrading an old turbine.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In thermal power stations, the reduction of erosion damage on turbine blades caused by ferric oxide particles that are exfoliated from the boiler and steam pipes is an urgent problem that needs to be addressed to guarantee the long-term, safe and high-efficiency operations of a unit.1 At present, a commonly used method for increasing the erosion resistance of a blade is to coat its surface with a layer of a hard coating substance. General Electric Co., Toshiba, Mitsubishi, EPRI and Professor Tabakoff et al. from the American Cincinnati University have reported some relevant studies. Thermal diffusion, thermal spraying and vapor deposition are the most common techniques used to strengthen the surface of blades.2–9

However, hard coating with limited thickness can only provide limited protection to the blade, and is often accompanied by an increase in the internal stress,10 which may shorten the service life of the blade. Furthermore, it is very difficult for the current technique to be completely free of coating defects, such as loose surfaces and cracks,11–13 all of which will undoubtedly lower the erosion resistance of the coating. In fact, it has been shown by practical engineering that it is impossible for these passive anti-erosion measures to completely solve the solid particle erosion (SPE) problem of turbine blades.14 Therefore, it is worth exploring alternative measures to reduce the erosion damage of blades, for example, optimizing the profile and cascade passage to reduce the SPE on the blade.

At present, the main idea for optimizing the erosion resistance of a blade is to decrease the incidence velocity of solid particles and avoid the incidence angle related to the high erosion rate of the material by improving the profile of the erodible blade.9,15 Toshiba6 and General Electric Co.16 have studied the anti-SPE blade of steam turbines since 1990, and have found that improved blades enjoy better erosion resistance. By performing numerical simulations, Campos-Amezcua17–19 observed an approximate linear increase in the erosion rate of blades with an increased steam velocity in the channel as well as the particle size. According to literature studies,15 removing the load toward the rear of the cascade can effectively lower the incidence velocity of particles on the blade, for example, applying an end-wall contraction or aft-loading blade. Furthermore, Dai et al.20 also discovered that the application of an end-wall contraction will reduce the maximum erosion rate and erosion area by about 40% and 30%, respectively. However, all of these achievements explore only the effectiveness of specific anti-erosion measures, and there remains a lack of systematic research on the internal relationship between blade structures and erosion resistance.

In this article, we systematically analyze the relationship between the erosion distribution of the blade and various parameters, such as the blade profile, particle impingement parameter and particle property, and the required basic elements of an anti-erosion blade and the internal relationship between various parameters were discovered. Furthermore, to estimate the erosion resistance of the blade, we established a set of characteristic parameters which can be used to guide the blade selection and anti-SPE optimization when designing a new turbine or upgrading an old turbine.

sec.title: Research methods
sec.p:
To explore the relationship between the blade profile and erosion resistance, multiple series of cascade models with single parameters that changed continuously were established by changing the pitch and setting angle of six typical blade profiles shown in Figure 1. Furthermore, the movements of steam and solid particles within the cascade were simulated using computational fluid dynamics software to analyze the impact of various parameters on the erosion of the blade and to explore the characteristic parameters representing the erosion resistance of the blade. Figure 1.
Parameters and blade profiles: (a) definition of parameters and (b) profiles of six kinds of blade.

To compare the erosion of particles having the same surface area, the relative surface coordinates (sr,r) were defined. sr=s/sl, where sl is the total arc length along the pressure surface of blade, s is the arc length from the leading edge to the erosion point of the particles, as shown in Figure 1 (a), and r is the radial distance from the erosion point to the rotation center of the rotor.

An existing study15 has indicated that about 10−4–10−3 mg ferric oxides particles are carried in 1 kg of steam. In view of such dilute-phase steam–particle movement, the steam flow field can be simulated using the Euler method, and the movement of particles and their interaction with the wall can be simulated using the Lagrange method. Each cascade is dispersed through about 600,000 O–H type multi-block structural grids. To simulate the compressible viscous flow within the cascade of steam turbines, the time-averaging continuity equation, Navier–Stokes (N–S) equation and energy equation were solved by an implicit equation discrete and coupled solver, and the turbulence viscosity in the N–S equation was estimated using the renormalization group k-ɛ model. The areas near the wall were processed using the scalable wall-function method, while the status parameters of steam were provided by the IAPWS-IF97 database. The abovementioned numerical simulation has been verified by existing literature studies.15,20,21 The boundary condition was set to be in accordance with the aerodynamic parameters of the regulating stage in the ultra-supercritical steam turbine: inlet pressure, 25 MPa; temperature, 600 ℃; attack angle of steam admission, 0°; turbulence intensity, 5% and outlet Mach number, Ma1.1 = 0.78. Ma1.1 is the weighted average of the steam mass flow for the Mach number at the 1–1 plane (x/bx = 1.1, as shown in Figure 1).

Table 1 shows the size distribution of ferric oxide particles in the steam turbine, which are from the statistical and mass equivalent analysis on many real particles. In this article, the particle sizes and their mass distribution were set according to Table 1. The total concentration of all particles was set as 1 × 10−3 mg particles per kilogram of steam, and 1000 seeding points were distributed evenly in the 0–0 plane (x/bx = −0.5, as shown in Figure 1) for every cascade. Table 1.
The size distributions of ferric oxide particles in the steam turbine.
Equivalent diameter (µm) Mass distribution (%)
5 0.1
10 1.0
20 10.3
40 29.8
60 24.1
80 18.5
100 11.2
120 3.1
140 1.6
160 0.3

According to our experimental result of high-temperature erosion,15 extremely similar erosion and rebound characters were observed in several different blade materials. This article selected one typical material, known as 1Cr11MoCo3W2, as the blade material for the numerical simulations, and we discovered the relationship between the erosion rate, experimental temperature T, incidence angle β and the particle velocity V ɛ=KT (T )Q (β )Vn(β) where15 KT (T )=2.5004-0.0017774TQ (β )=-0.00097233+1.738β-2.942β2 +1.844β3+0.40405β4n (β )=2.7518-0.011058β-0.094253β2 +0.020457β3

The rebound characteristic of flaky ferric oxide particles after impinging the blade is15 eT(β)=V2TV1T(β)=0.9995-4.1253β+8.3113β2 -8.7318β3+4.5615β4-0.9283β5eN(β)=V2NV1N(β)=0.9991-1.051β+1.4972β2 -0.804β3+0.1766β4 where β is the particle impinging angle, and eT(β) and eN(β) are the tangential and the normal velocity restitution coefficients of particles after rebound, respectively. We introduced the abovementioned model into ANSYS CFX, and the particle trajectory, the erosion distribution of weight loss E(sr,r), impingement points distribution of particles N(sr,r), incidence velocity distribution V(sr,r) and the incidence angle distribution β(sr,r) under different working conditions can be obtained by iteration operations.

sec.title: Analysis of characteristic parameter
sec.p:
The basic movement and erosion characteristic of solid particles in cascade will be illustrated through the blade with profile B1, chord length b = 91.37 mm and t/b = 0.665. The distributions of the incidence velocity and the incidence angle of 80 µm particles along the axial direction of the blade are shown in Figure 2, in which type I represented the first impingement point of every particle on the surface of the blade after entering into the cascade, and type II represented the additional impingement points of the particle on the wall after rebounding. It can be seen from Figure 2(a) that the incidence angles for most type I cases were within the range 15–30°, which is just within the angle range of the maximum erosion rate of the blade material.13,22,23 However, the incidence angles for most type II cases were smaller than 6 because the oxide particles were flaky and preferred to roll near the wall after the first impingement on the wall, after which they hit the wall again before the pressure surface curvature changed significantly. It can also be seen from Figure 2(b) that the incidence velocity for type I was a little higher than that of type II. Figure 2.
The difference in the incidence parameters between type I and type II for the profile B1 at b=91.37 mm, t/b=0.665 and Dp=80 µm: (a) variation of β vs. x/bx and (b) variation of V vs. x/bx.

This study focuses more on the erosion characteristic of the area within sr = 0.9–1.0 where almost all erosion damage to the stator blade is concentrated. Furthermore, the following four statistical parameters were defined to represent the particles’ erosion rate, impingement probability, incidence velocity and incidence angle within the area of sr = 0.9–1.0 for 10,000 h (1)E0.9-1.0=∫0 10000∫0.9 1.0∫rh rsE (sr,r )drdsrdτ
(2)P0.9-1.0=1n∫0.9 1.0∫rh rsN (sr,r )drdsr×100%
(3)V0.9-1.0=∫0.9 1.0∫rh rsV(sr,r)E(sr,r)drdsr∫0.9 1.0∫rh rsE(sr,r)drdsr
(4)β0.9-1.0=∫0.9 1.0∫rh rsβ (sr,r )E (sr,r )drdsr∫0.9 1.0∫rh rsE (sr,r )drdsr where rh and rs are the radius of the hub and shroud of the blade, respectively, and n is the number of particles that entered into the cascade. Considering the significant impact of different incidence velocities and incidence angle distributions on the erosion rate, V0.9-1.0 and β0.9-1.0 applied the weighted average velocity and angle of the erosion rate.

The study on particles’ movement in the cascade, which was conducted by Dring et al.,24 showed that the particle trajectory was mainly determined by the following two dimensionless parameters (5)St=ρpVs0Dp 218μs0bx
(6)σ=Rebxρp/ρs0 where Rebx=ρs0Vs0bxμs0, ρp is the density of the solid particle, ρs0 is the density of steam at the inlet of the cascade, Vs0 is the steam flow velocity at the inlet of the cascade, Dp is the diameter of the solid particle, μs0 is the steam dynamic viscosity at the inlet of the cascade and bx is the axial width of the blade. Given a fixed blade size and aerodynamic parameter, the St number is only related to Dp. Therefore, it is difficult to change the range of the St number while designing or optimizing a steam turbine.

The statistical results for various parameters are shown in Figure 3 when the profile B1 at t/b = 0.75 and t/b = 0.665 (b = 91.37 mm). It can be seen that E0.9–1.0 for type II was at a lower level and hardly changes with the St number. Although the impingement points for type I were less than 50% of type II, type I causes decisive erosion damage to the blade under most St numbers since it has a much larger incidence angle and incidence velocity than that of type II. This is a basic characteristic of blade erosion, which was not further displayed for other particles here due to space restrictions. Based on the comparison between Figure 3(a) and (b), a significant variation difference of E0.9–1.0 with an St number of type I impingement can be easily observed in a different blade, and P0.9–1.0 is the main cause of the variation in E0.9–1.0 with the St number. All of these characteristics demonstrated that it is feasible to reduce the number of type I cases in sr = 0.9–1.0 by choosing an appropriate blade profile and cascade structure when considering the particle size. This is also one of the main ways to improve the erosion resistance of the blade. Therefore, the following discussion will focus on type I impingement, and unless stated otherwise, all impingement points refer only to type I. Figure 3.
The statistical results of various parameters for the profile B1 at t/b=0.75 and t/b=0.665: (a) variation of E0.9-1.0 vs. St, (b) variation of P0.9-1.0 vs. St, (c) variation of V0.9-1.0 vs. St and (d) variation of β0.9-1.0 vs. St.

Figure 4 shows the particle trajectory and type I impingement in the cascade. It can be seen that particles that are evenly distributed at the inlet of the cascade along the circumference impinge different successive positions on the pressure surfaces of the blade. The particle impingement on only the trailing edge of adjacent blade with its trajectory laid closely on the suction surface is called a critical impingement, as shown in Figure 4(b). Therefore, it is easy to infer that some particles may escape by increasing the pitch of the cascade in Figure 4(b), but the number of impingement points as well as the impingement positions on the pressure surface of the blade would basically remain unchanged, as shown in Figure 4(a). However, decreasing the pitch of the cascade in Figure 4(b) will reduce or even eliminate particles impinging on the trailing edge, as shown in Figure 4(c). Similarly, based on the blade in Figure 4(b), decreasing by of blade will increase the number of escaped particles, and increasing by of the blade will decrease the type I impingement on the trailing edge. Therefore, the key to optimizing the erosion resistance of the blade is to determine the structural parameters of the blade when considering the critical impingement of particles. Figure 4.
The trajectory and type I impingement of particles in the cascade.

The axial displacement of particles producing critical impingement from the inlet of the cascade to the impingement point can be easily calculated as bx and the circumferential displacement is calculated as by−t. Apparently, the critical impingement was mainly determined by the relative size of by−t and bx under the same aerodynamic parameters and particle property. Hence, a parameter G = (by−t)/bx was defined in this article to represent the cascade structure corresponding to the critical impingement. Furthermore, the ratio of escaped particles to the total number of particles entered into the cascade is defined as the escape rate, and is expressed by e.

sec.title: Results and discussions
sec.p:
Given a certain chord length and the flow outlet angle of profile B1, a series of cascades with different G values was constructed by adjusting the pitch and setting angle, and aims to study the impact of parameter G on blade erosion. Their parameters are shown in Table 2. Furthermore, three groups of cascades with the same G value but different profiles were constructed by changing the pitch and setting angle of six blade profiles in Figure 1. Their parameters are shown in Table 3, Table 4, and Table 5, respectively. Table 2.
Parameters of cascades with different G and same profile.
1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9
Profile B1 B1 B1 B1 B1 B1 B1 B1 B1
b/mm 94.37 94.37 94.37 94.37 94.37 94.37 94.37 94.37 94.37
G 0.212 0.243 0.292 0.339 0.386 0.432 0.489 0.534 0.577
α1/° 15.18 15.18 15.18 15.18 15.18 15.18 15.18 15.18 15.18
t/b 0.75 0.728 0.697 0.665 0.633 0.601 0.552 0.53 0.490
Table 3.
Parameters of cascades with different profile and same G(=0.292).
1 2 3 4 5
Profile B6 B5 B4 B3 B1
b/mm 94.37 94.37 94.37 94.37 94.37
G 0.292 0.292 0.292 0.292 0.292
α1/° 15.18 15.18 15.18 15.18 15.18
t/b 0.538 0.551 0.671 0.688 0.697
Table 4.
Parameters of cascades with different profile and same G(=0.489).
1 2 3 4
Profile B4 B3 B1 B2
b/mm 94.37 94.37 94.37 94.37
G 0.489 0.489 0.489 0.489
α1/° 15.18 15.18 15.18 15.18
t/b 0.509 0.537 0.552 0.563
Table 5.
Parameters of cascades with different profile and same G(=0.577).
1 2 3 4
Profile B4 B3 B1 B2
b/mm 94.37 94.37 94.37 94.37
G 0.577 0.577 0.577 0.577
α1/° 15.18 15.18 15.18 15.18
t/b 0.434 0.469 0.490 0.501

The variation of the escape rate e of nine types of cascade in Table 2 with St number is shown in Figure 5(a). It reveals that for the same cascade, the escape rate e decreases with an increased St number, and the St number at the turning point from the escape rate (e>0) to zero escape (e = 0) corresponds to the critical impingement of this cascade, which is referred to as Stcr. Each cascade has only one Stcr. With the increase in G, both Stcr and e under the same St number decrease. Figure 5(b) shows the variation of the escape rate e of five types of cascade in Table 3 with St number, which revealed that although these five cascades have different blade types and different relative pitch t/b, they have the same Stcr and almost the same variation law of e with the St number due to the same G value (0.292). All of these results reconfirmed that G is one of the key cascade structural parameters that represent the erosion resistance of blades. Figure 5.
The statistical results of particle escape rate: (a) variation of e vs. St for the cascades with different G, (b) variation of e vs. St for the cascades with different t/b and (c) variation of e vs. St for the cascades with different α.

With respect to using a stationary blade for the regulating stage and the first stage after reheating in steam turbines, the attack angle α of steam admission is often nonzero. The variation of e of cascade 1 in Table 2 with the St number under four different α is shown in Figure 5(c). It can be seen that both e and Stcr decrease with an increase in α, achieving basically the same effect as increasing G. Increasing α from 0° to 15° is similar to increasing G from 0.212 to 0.339, and increasing α to 45° is similar to increasing G to 0.489. Apparently, α is the key aerodynamic parameter representing the erosion resistance of the blade. Therefore, it is very necessary to consider its influence when selecting G.

The variations of E0.9–1.0 and P0.9–1.0 with the St number are shown in Figures 6 and 7, respectively, for the nine types of cascade in Table 2. It can be seen that both the St numbers corresponding to the maximum value of E0.9–1.0 and E0.9–1.0 under the same St number decrease with the increasing G, achieving extremely similar variation trends to that of P0.9–1.0. These results demonstrated again that the impingement probability is the primary cause of type I variation with the St number. Based on the above analysis, it can be concluded that the impingement positions of particles shift gradually toward the leading edge of the blade with increasing G, and will eventually extend beyond the area of sr = 0.9–1.0. Under this circumstance, E0.9–1.0 and P0.9–1.0 will be zero, and the blade erosion damage will be reduced significantly. Obviously, for larger G, the St range of E0.9–1.0 = 0 will be wider, and the blade will be more secure. When G ≥ 0.489, all particles with St >14 were beyond the area of sr = 0.9–1.0, which suggests that basically no type I common solid particles impinge on the trailing edge, thus significantly increasing the service life of the blade. Figure 6.
The statistical results of erosion rate for the cascades with different G: (a) variation of E0.9-1.0 vs. St when G≤0.386 and (b) variation of E0.9-1.0 vs. St when G≥0.386.
Figure 7.
The statistical results of impingement probability for the cascades with different G: (a) variation of P0.9-1.0 vs. St when G≤0.386 and (b) variation of P0.9-1.0 vs. St when G≥0.386.

The influence of α on the variation of E0.9–1.0 with St when G = 0.292 and G = 0.432 is presented in Figure 8. It can be seen that increasing α and increasing G can achieve a similar effect: the impingement position of particles on the blade shifts forward gradually, and the St number corresponding to the maximum E0.9–1.0 and E0.9–1.0 at the same St decreases. The erosion law at G = 0.292 and α=45∘ is similar to that at G = 0.534 and α=0∘, and the erosion law at G = 0.432 and α=45∘ is similar to that at G = 0.577 and α=0∘. Upon analysis from the perspective of the trajectory of the particles, increasing α is equivalent to decreasing the circumferential displacement under the same axial displacement, shifting the impingement position toward the upstream of the blade. However, it failed to deduce the quantitative relationship due to the numerous influencing factors. Figure 8.
The statistical results of erosion rate for the cascades with different α: (a) variation of E0.9-1.0 vs. St when G=0.292 and (b) variation of E0.9-1.0 vs. St when G=0.432.

Figure 9 shows the influence of the relative pitch t/b on the variation of E0.9–1.0 with the St number when G = 0.292, G = 0.490 and G = 0.577, and indicated that the variation law of E0.9–1.0 with the St number depends only on the value of G, while t/b mainly influences the value of E0.9–1.0. Given G = 0.292, for a larger t/b, E0.9–1.0 will be higher. When G = 0.490 and G = 0.577, t/b has only a very weak influence on E0.9–1.0, without the obvious law. Figure 9.
The statistical results of erosion rate for the cascades with different t/b: (a) variation of E0.9-1.0 vs. St when G=0.292, (b) variation of E0.9-1.0 vs. St when G=0.489 and (c) variation of E0.9-1.0 vs. St when G=0.577.

Figure 10 shows the influence of parameter σ on the variation of E0.9–1.0 and P0.9–1.0 with St number when G = 0.339. Four different values of σ were acquired by scaling the cascade 4 in Table 2. Figure 10 demonstrated that as σ increases, particles remain in the cascade for a longer time due to the increased bx, but they perform better when following the steam flow, thus increasing the St number that corresponds to the maximum E0.9–1.0 and P0.9–1.0. However, changing σ generally has less influence on particle impingement and erosion compared with changing G or α. The size of the cascade obtained with a maximum σ is four times that obtained with a minimum σ in Figure 10, but it is impossible to have such a wide selection of cascade size ranges when designing a steam turbine. However, due to the limited variation of impingement positions, the erosion resistance of the blade is not easily improved by changing σ. Figure 10.
The statistical results of erosion rate and impingement probability for different σ: (a) variation of E0.9 ~1.0 vs. St when G=0.339 and (b) variation of P0.9-1.0 vs. St when G=0.339.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this article, we presented a systematic study of the relationship between the structural characteristics of cascades and erosion parameters such as particle erosion distribution and the impingement probability by performing multiple three-dimensional numerical simulations. The results show that the incidence angles of type I (the first impingement point of every particle on the surface of the blade after entering into the cascade) is much larger than that of type II (additional impingement point of particles on the surface of the blade). Therefore, the type I impingement is shown to cause the main erosion damage to the blade. In addition, the structural parameter of cascade (G), attack angle of steam admission (α) and aerodynamic parameters (St and σ) are the main influencing parameters of the impingement position and erosion distribution. Increasing G and α can shift the impingement position toward the leading edge of the blade, and can reduce or even eliminate type I impingement in the area of sr = 0.9–1.0, hence reducing the erosion damage of the blade significantly. Furthermore, although decreasing σ can achieve a similar effect to increasing G, it is less influential. The scope of the St number is not easily changed because it is determined mainly by the size of the oxide particles. Reducing the amount of type I in sr = 0.9–1.0 by choosing an appropriate blade profile and cascade structure when considering the particle size is one of the main ways that can be employed to improve the erosion resistance of the blade.
